TITLE: Meta Is Said to Plan Significant Job Cuts This Week
SUMMARY: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, said last month that many “teams will stay flat or shrink over the next year” as his company faces economic challenges.

TITLE: Meta Is Said to Plan Significant Layoffs This Week
SUMMARY: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, said last month that many “teams will stay flat or shrink over the next year” as his company faces economic challenges.

TITLE: Lucid Said It Will Raise Up to $1.5 Billion in Capital
SUMMARY: The electric carmaker made the announcement on the same day it reported losing $670 million in the third quarter.

TITLE: Herman Daly, 84, Who Challenged the Economic Gospel of Growth, Dies
SUMMARY: Perhaps the best-known ecological economist, he faulted his mainstream peers for failing to account for the environmental harm growth can bring.

TITLE: Inflation Plagues Democrats in Polling. Will It Crush Them at the Ballot Box?
SUMMARY: Americans are extremely attuned to the cost of living, and as midterm election voters head to the polls, they are divided over whom to blame.

TITLE: An Inflation-Driven Midterm Will Not Change Biden’s Economic Focus
SUMMARY: The president said he would not change his economic approach, adding that his policies were working.

TITLE: After Months of Stubborn Inflation, Glimmers of Hope Emerge
SUMMARY: The Consumer Price Index showed that prices climbed 7.7 percent in the year through October, a quick pace but a notable moderation.

TITLE: Price of Diesel, Which Powers the Economy, Is Still Climbing
SUMMARY: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is one reason that the fuel is scarce. Another is a series of yearslong, intertwined events that cover the globe.

TITLE: As the Fed Raises Rates, Worries Grow About Corporate Bonds
SUMMARY: Executives, analysts and bond traders are all wondering if corporate finance is about to unravel as interest rates rise.

TITLE: Tech’s Talent Wars Have Come Back to Bite It
SUMMARY: Hiring the best, the brightest and the highest number of employees was a badge of honor at tech companies. Not anymore as layoffs surge.

TITLE: U.K. Economy Shrinks as Threat of Recession Nears
SUMMARY: Britain’s economic output fell in the third quarter and European Union officials forecast weakening growth for countries across the continent.

TITLE: Yellen Calls for ‘Stabilizing’ U.S. Relations With China Ahead of G20
SUMMARY: The Treasury secretary said in an interview that the United States was not trying to “paralyze China’s economy and stop its development.”

TITLE: Walmart Defies Gloom Over Inflation With Sales and Profit Upgrade
SUMMARY: Ahead of the critical holiday shopping season, the nation’s largest retailer reported stronger-than-expected earnings and signaled confidence with a $20 billion share buyback.

TITLE: Is Rock Climbing the Future of Tourism in Malawi?
SUMMARY: The small country in southeastern Africa is leveraging its little-known rock cliffs and boulders to develop local interest in climbing — and to draw adventure tourists.

TITLE: World Leaders Meet as Global Economy Faces Multiple Threats
SUMMARY: High inflation, food insecurity and a possible global recession loom large as the Group of 20 summit discussions begin.

TITLE: Amazon Is Said to Plan to Lay Off Approximately 10,000 Employees
SUMMARY: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.

TITLE: Foreign Trade Competition Has Hurt Black and Disadvantaged Workers Most, Report Says
SUMMARY: A government trade agency report suggested that the impact of trade policy differed for workers depending on their race and socioeconomic status.

TITLE: G20 Leaders Meet in Bali as Global Economy Faces Multiple Threats
SUMMARY: High inflation, food insecurity and a possible global recession loom large as the Group of 20 summit discussions begin.

TITLE: US Shoppers Are Still Spending, as Long as Retailers Give Them a Reason
SUMMARY: Retail sales rose last month, and several companies reported strong earnings. But discounts seemed to drive a significant portion of purchases.

TITLE: Henry Rosovsky, Who Redefined Harvard to Its Core, Dies at 95
SUMMARY: As dean of the faculty, he diplomatically persuaded his colleagues to tighten requirements for a degree and create a Black studies program.

TITLE: Will Taxing the Windfall Profits of Oil Giants Fix Countries’ Economies?
SUMMARY: Britain is raising a tax on gas and oil producers, and adding a levy on companies that supply electricity — a similar approach to that of other governments chasing revenue.

TITLE: Starbucks Workers Strike at Dozens of Stores Nationally
SUMMARY: Workers said they were protesting the company’s refusal to bargain in good faith and other anti-union activity.

TITLE: Henry Rosovsky, 95, Builder of Black and Jewish Studies at Harvard, Dies
SUMMARY: As dean of the faculty, he diplomatically persuaded his colleagues to tighten requirements for a degree and create a Black studies program.

TITLE: Oil Prices Slide as Investors Worry Energy Demand Is Slowing
SUMMARY: The U.S. benchmark oil price fell to about $80 a barrel on Friday, and gasoline prices in some states are now close to $3 a gallon.

TITLE: Are the Federal Reserve’s Rate Increases Working?
SUMMARY: The Fed’s campaign to slow the economy is gradually taking hold, but officials have been particularly surprised by the job market's resilience.

TITLE: Key Freight Rail Union Rejects Deal, Increasing Strike Risk
SUMMARY: The tentative agreement, brokered in September with help from the Biden administration, had averted a strike before the midterm elections.

TITLE: U.S. Blocks Dominican Republic Sugar Imports, Citing Forced Labor
SUMMARY: An import ban targets sugar from Central Romana Corporation, a sugar behemoth whose sugar is sold under the Domino, Florida Crystals and C&H brands.

TITLE: Billions of Dollars at Stake in a Puzzling Holiday Shopping Season
SUMMARY: It promises to be unpredictable, with retailers and consumers still figuring out how much will be spent and on what kinds of goods.

TITLE: Fed Officials Discussed Slowing Interest Rate Increases ‘Soon’
SUMMARY: The central bankers discussed the need to slow rate increases soon at their last meeting, while signaling that they are likely to raise borrowing costs higher.

TITLE: Billions of Dollars Are at Stake in a Puzzling Holiday Shopping Season
SUMMARY: It promises to be unpredictable, with retailers and consumers still figuring out how much will be spent and on what kinds of goods.

TITLE: A Holiday Season Divided by Inflation and Economic Struggles
SUMMARY: Even if policymakers achieve a gentle economic slowdown, it won’t be smooth for everyone.

TITLE: Gina Raimondo, a Rising Star in the Biden Administration, Faces a $100 Billion Test
SUMMARY: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, has made a career of tackling increasingly larger challenges. Could the next one be too big?

TITLE: Black Friday Shoppers Worry About Economy as Retailers Push Sales
SUMMARY: Black Friday deals returned, drawing shoppers back into stores, but inflation worries left many companies unsure what the holiday shopping season would look like.

TITLE: Why Retailers Are Trying Extra Hard to Woo Holiday Shoppers
SUMMARY: With an economic slowdown a distinct possibility, stores hope customers’ willingness to open their wallets will last through the season.

TITLE: Chinese Unrest Over Lockdown Upends Global Economic Outlook
SUMMARY: Growing protests in the world’s biggest manufacturing nation add a new element of uncertainty atop the Ukraine war, an energy crisis and inflation.

TITLE: Michael Pertschuk, Antismoking and Auto Safety Crusader, Dies at 89
SUMMARY: As an obscure but muscular congressional staffer and chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, he helped usher into law a raft of consumer protections.

TITLE: Leaders in Congress Say They Will Act to Prevent Rail Strike
SUMMARY: Democratic and Republican leaders prepared to intercede as President Biden warned the prospect of a December strike put the U.S. economy “at risk.”

TITLE: Job Openings Ease, but Layoffs Are Little Changed
SUMMARY: Government data for October shows the labor market is still strong, though cooling slightly.

TITLE: David Lipton, Economic Diplomat, Will Step Down From Treasury
SUMMARY: Mr. Lipton, who served in senior roles in the Clinton and Obama administrations and at the I.M.F., is retiring.

TITLE: Economist Austan Goolsbee Is Named to Lead the Chicago Fed
SUMMARY: A longtime University of Chicago economist who served in the Obama White House will be president of one of the Fed’s 12 regional districts.

TITLE: Despite Inflation, Consumers Kept Up Their Spending in October
SUMMARY: Consumption climbed and personal income rose, even after accounting for inflation, new data from the Commerce Department showed.

TITLE: California Panel Sizes Up Reparations for Black Citizens
SUMMARY: The state is undertaking the nation’s most ambitious effort so far to compensate for the economic legacy of slavery and racism.

TITLE: Chinese Solar Makers Evaded U.S. Tariffs, Investigation Finds
SUMMARY: The Biden administration pre-emptively halted any penalties from the case in June, prompting critics to say the administration had shortcut its own trade rules

TITLE: U.S. Job Growth Remains Strong, Defying Fed’s Rate Strategy
SUMMARY: Employers added 263,000 workers in November, even as some industries showed signs of a slowdown. Wage growth exceeded expectations.

TITLE: Stocks Shudder After a Surprisingly Strong Jobs Report
SUMMARY: The labor market remains strong, complicating the picture for the Federal Reserve. Investors are expecting the central bank to soon start slowing interest rate increases.

TITLE: Why Are Middle-Aged Men Missing From the Labor Market?
SUMMARY: Men ages 35 to 44 are staging a lackluster rebound from pandemic job loss, despite a strong economy.

TITLE: ‘Innovation Hubs’ Aim to Lift Distressed Areas. Congress Just Has to Fund Them.
SUMMARY: A new report suggests where 20 newly created research centers could best revitalize struggling economies and accelerate new technologies

TITLE: Computer Science Students Face a Shrinking Big Tech Job Market
SUMMARY: A new reality is setting in for students and recent graduates who spent years honing themselves for careers at the largest tech companies.

TITLE: Global Car Supply Chains Entangled With Abuses in Xinjiang, Report Says
SUMMARY: A new report on the auto industry cites extensive links to Xinjiang, where the U.S. government now presumes goods are made with forced labor.

TITLE: Are You Applying for Tech Jobs or Internships? We Want to Hear About It.
SUMMARY: Layoffs and hiring freezes at companies like Amazon and Meta are changing the job market for recent grads and college students. Tell us about your experiences.

TITLE: If There Is a ‘Male Malaise’ With Work, Could One Answer Be at Sea?
SUMMARY: As concerns about labor force participation among American men mount, maritime transportation firms are desperate for new mariners.

TITLE: US Proposes Global Green Steel Club That Would Put Tariffs on China
SUMMARY: A concept paper sent to the European Union suggests a new trade approach to tax metal made with higher carbon emissions in countries like China.

TITLE: In Appalachia, Margo Miller Leads from “a Place of Courageous Joy”
SUMMARY: Ms. Miller’s work has made her one of the most powerful people in philanthropy in a rapidly evolving region that has long been marred by stereotypes.

TITLE: Workers at E.V. Battery Plant in Ohio Vote to Unionize
SUMMARY: The result, at a plant owned by General Motors and a South Korean company, is a milestone for the auto union in organizing electric vehicle workers.

TITLE: Biden Devotes $36 Billion to Save Union Workers’ Pensions
SUMMARY: The money comes from last year’s Covid-19 relief package and will avert cuts of up to 60 percent in pensions for 350,000 Teamster truck drivers, warehouse and construction workers and food processors.

TITLE: Yellen Is First Female Treasury Secretary With Signature on U.S. Dollar
SUMMARY: Two women — the first female Treasury secretary and the first Native American to serve as U.S. treasurer — now have their signatures on America’s currency.

TITLE: Inflation Forecasts Were Wrong Last Year. Should We Believe Them Now?
SUMMARY: Economists misjudged how much staying power inflation would have. Next year could be better — but there’s ample room for humility.
